"**With a Little Help from My Friends** " is a song by the English rock band
[the Beatles](/wiki/The_Beatles "The Beatles") from their 1967 album _[Sgt.
Pepper's Lonely Hearts Club
Band](/wiki/Sgt._Pepper%27s_Lonely_Hearts_Club_Band "Sgt. Pepper's Lonely
Hearts Club Band")_. It was written by [John Lennon](/wiki/John_Lennon "John
Lennon") and [Paul McCartney](/wiki/Paul_McCartney "Paul McCartney"), and
intended as the album's featured vocal for drummer [Ringo
Starr](/wiki/Ringo_Starr "Ringo Starr"). The group recorded the song towards
the end of the sessions for _Sgt. Pepper_ , with Starr singing as the
character "[Billy Shears](/wiki/Billy_Shears "Billy Shears")".

A subsequent recording of the track by [Joe Cocker](/wiki/Joe_Cocker "Joe
Cocker") became a hit single in 1968 and an anthem for the
[Woodstock](/wiki/Woodstock "Woodstock") era.[2] In 1978, the Beatles'
recording, paired with "[Sgt. Pepper's Lonely Hearts Club
Band](/wiki/Sgt._Pepper%27s_Lonely_Hearts_Club_Band_\(song\) "Sgt. Pepper's
Lonely Hearts Club Band \(song\)")", was reissued as a single, and peaked at
number 63 in Britain and number 71 in the United States. Starr has regularly
performed the song in concert as a solo artist. "With a Little Help from My
Friends" was ranked number 311 on _[Rolling Stone](/wiki/Rolling_Stone
"Rolling Stone")_ 's list of the [500 Greatest Songs of All
Time](/wiki/500_Greatest_Songs_of_All_Time "500 Greatest Songs of All Time").

## Origins

Lennon and McCartney finished writing this song in mid-March 1967,[3] written
specifically as Starr's track for the album. McCartney said: "It was pretty
much co-written, John and I doing a work song for Ringo, a little craft job."
In 1970 Lennon stated: "Paul had the line about 'a little help from my
friends.' He had some kind of structure for it, and we wrote it pretty well
fifty-fifty from his original idea.", but in 1980 Lennon said: "This is Paul,
with a little help from me. 'What do you see when you turn out the light/ I
can't tell you, but I know it's mine...' is mine."[4] It was briefly called
"Bad Finger Boogie" (later the inspiration for the band name
[Badfinger](/wiki/Badfinger "Badfinger")),[5] supposedly because Lennon
composed the melody on a piano using his middle finger after having hurt his
forefinger.

The song begins with the applause from the end of [Sgt. Pepper's Lonely Hearts
Club Band](/wiki/Sgt._Pepper%27s_Lonely_Hearts_Club_Band_\(song\) "Sgt.
Pepper's Lonely Hearts Club Band \(song\)").

Lennon and McCartney deliberately wrote a tune with a limited range – except
for the last note, which McCartney worked closely with Starr to achieve.
Speaking in the _[Anthology](/wiki/The_Beatles_Anthology "The Beatles
Anthology")_ , Starr explained that he insisted on changing the first line —
which originally was "What would you think if I sang out of tune? Would you
throw ripe tomatoes at me?" — so that fans would not throw tomatoes at him
should he perform it live. (In the early days, after [George
Harrison](/wiki/George_Harrison "George Harrison") made a passing comment that
he liked [jelly babies](/wiki/Jelly_babies "Jelly babies"), the group was
showered with them at all of their live performances.)[6]

The song's composition is unusually well documented, as [Hunter
Davies](/wiki/Hunter_Davies "Hunter Davies") was present and described the
writing process in the Beatles' official biography.

The song is partly in the form of a conversation in which the other three
Beatles sing a question — e.g. "Would you believe in a love at first sight?"
where Starr answers, "Yes, I'm certain that it happens all the time."

## Recording

The Beatles began recording the song on 29 March 1967, the day before they
posed for the _Sgt. Pepper_ album cover. They recorded 10 takes of the song,
wrapping up sessions at 5:45 in the morning.[7] The backing track consisted of
Starr on drums, McCartney playing piano, Harrison playing lead guitar and
Lennon beating a cowbell. At dawn, Starr trudged up the stairs to head home –
but the other Beatles cajoled him into doing his lead vocal then and there,
standing around the microphone for moral support.[4] The following day they
added tambourine, backing vocals, bass and more electric guitar.[7]

## Personnel

According to [Ian MacDonald](/wiki/Ian_MacDonald "Ian MacDonald"), except
where noted:[8]

  * [Ringo Starr](/wiki/Ringo_Starr "Ringo Starr") – lead vocal, drums
  * [John Lennon](/wiki/John_Lennon "John Lennon") – backing vocal, [cowbell](/wiki/Cowbell_\(instrument\) "Cowbell \(instrument\)")
  * [Paul McCartney](/wiki/Paul_McCartney "Paul McCartney") – backing vocal, piano, bass guitar
  * [George Harrison](/wiki/George_Harrison "George Harrison") – backing vocal, rhythm[9] and lead guitars
  * [George Martin](/wiki/George_Martin "George Martin") – [Hammond organ](/wiki/Hammond_organ "Hammond organ")

## Live performances

To date, Starr has closed every concert performed by each version of his [All-
Starr Band](/wiki/Ringo_Starr_%26_His_All-Starr_Band "Ringo Starr & His All-
Starr Band") with this song. After he is done singing, Starr tells the
audience "Peace and love...peace and love is the only way...and good night",
then walks off the stage. Since 2008, the band segued right into "[Give Peace
a Chance](/wiki/Give_Peace_a_Chance "Give Peace a Chance")", during which
Starr comes back onstage, then walks off again.

Starr performed the song with [George Harrison](/wiki/George_Harrison "George
Harrison"), [Eric Clapton](/wiki/Eric_Clapton "Eric Clapton"), [Bruce
Springsteen](/wiki/Bruce_Springsteen "Bruce Springsteen"), [George
Michael](/wiki/George_Michael "George Michael"), [Phil
Collins](/wiki/Phil_Collins "Phil Collins"), [Elton John](/wiki/Elton_John
"Elton John"), and many others at the 1987 [Prince's
Trust](/wiki/Prince%27s_Trust "Prince's Trust") Concert at [Wembley
Arena](/wiki/Wembley_Arena "Wembley Arena"), London.[10]

McCartney and Starr performed this song for the first time together at the
[David Lynch Foundation](/wiki/David_Lynch_Foundation "David Lynch
Foundation") Benefit Concert in the [Radio City Music
Hall](/wiki/Radio_City_Music_Hall "Radio City Music Hall"), New York on 4
April 2009. McCartney and Starr also performed the song together on "The Night
That Changed America: A Grammy Salute to The Beatles", a commemorative show on
27 January 2014, that marked 50 years since the band's first appearance on
_The Ed Sullivan Show_.[11], then again in 2015 at Ringo Starr's induction in
the Rock'n Roll Hall of Fame.[12]

## Cover versions

There have been at least 50 cover versions of the song[13] and it has achieved
the number one position on the British singles charts three times: by [Joe
Cocker](/wiki/Joe_Cocker "Joe Cocker") in 1968,[14] [Wet Wet
Wet](/wiki/Wet_Wet_Wet "Wet Wet Wet") in 1988,[15] and by [Sam &
Mark](/wiki/Sam_%26_Mark "Sam & Mark") in 2004. [Chris
Clark](/wiki/Chris_Clark_\(singer\) "Chris Clark \(singer\)"), the first white
female recording artist to have an album released on [Motown](/wiki/Motown
"Motown"), recorded the song for her second album, 1969's _[CC Rides
Again](/wiki/CC_Rides_Again "CC Rides Again")_.

The song was also covered by [Mumford & Sons](/wiki/Mumford_%26_Sons "Mumford
& Sons") and [Dawes](/wiki/Dawes_\(band\) "Dawes \(band\)") on the Tour of Two
Halves in 2012.[16] Mumford & Sons also covered the song to close out their
headline set at the 2013 [Glastonbury Festival](/wiki/Glastonbury_Festival
"Glastonbury Festival") with [Vampire Weekend](/wiki/Vampire_Weekend "Vampire
Weekend"), [The Vaccines](/wiki/The_Vaccines "The Vaccines"), [First Aid
Kit](/wiki/First_Aid_Kit_\(band\) "First Aid Kit \(band\)"), and [The
Staves](/wiki/The_Staves "The Staves") on 30 June 2013.[17] For the 1981
compilation _[Rarities](/wiki/Rarities_\(The_Beach_Boys_album\) "Rarities
\(The Beach Boys album\)")_ , [the Beach Boys](/wiki/The_Beach_Boys "The Beach
Boys") released their version recorded in 1967,[18] while in 2015, [Brian
Wilson](/wiki/Brian_Wilson "Brian Wilson") named it one of his favorite
songs,[19] and in that year German rock band [Bonfire](/wiki/Bonfire_\(band\)
"Bonfire \(band\)"), with new frontman [David Reece](/wiki/David_Reece "David
Reece"), recorded their version for the album _Glörious_.

[Widespread Panic](/wiki/Widespread_Panic "Widespread Panic") has performed
the song twice, both times during their special 3-Set New Year's Eve
shows.[20]

In March 2017, [Broadway](/wiki/Broadway_theatre "Broadway theatre") and
Hollywood artists including [Liz Callaway](/wiki/Liz_Callaway "Liz Callaway"),
[FORTE](/wiki/Forte_\(vocal_group\) "Forte \(vocal group\)"), [Annie
Golden](/wiki/Annie_Golden "Annie Golden"), [Telly Leung](/wiki/Telly_Leung
"Telly Leung") and [Chris Mann](/wiki/Chris_Mann_\(singer\) "Chris Mann
\(singer\)") performed a gospel-flavored version of the song for a single and
video to benefit [Americans for the Arts](/wiki/Americans_for_the_Arts
"Americans for the Arts").[21]

## Joe Cocker version

English singer [Joe Cocker](/wiki/Joe_Cocker "Joe Cocker")'s version of "With
a Little Help from My Friends" was a radical re-arrangement of the original,
in a slower, **6**  
**8** meter, using different chords in the middle eight, and a lengthy
instrumental introduction (featuring drums by [Procol
Harum](/wiki/Procol_Harum "Procol Harum")'s [B.J. Wilson](/wiki/B.J._Wilson
"B.J. Wilson"), guitar lines from [Jimmy Page](/wiki/Jimmy_Page "Jimmy Page"),
and organ by [Tommy Eyre](/wiki/Tommy_Eyre "Tommy Eyre")). Cocker performed
the song at [Woodstock](/wiki/Woodstock_Festival "Woodstock Festival") in 1969
and that performance was included in the [documentary
film](/wiki/Documentary_film "Documentary film"),
_[Woodstock](/wiki/Woodstock_\(film\) "Woodstock \(film\)")_. This version
gained even more fame when it was used as the opening [theme
song](/wiki/Theme_song "Theme song") for the television series _[The Wonder
Years](/wiki/The_Wonder_Years "The Wonder Years")_.[22] Cocker's cover was
ranked number two in UpVenue's top 10 best music covers of all time in
2009.[23] In 2014, a [BBC](/wiki/BBC "BBC") poll saw it voted the seventh best
cover version ever.[24] The version heard in the film _[Across the
Universe](/wiki/Across_the_Universe_\(film\) "Across the Universe \(film\)")_
segues from the original to Cocker's arrangement at the end of the song. In
2001, Cocker's version of the song was inducted into the [Grammy Hall of
Fame](/wiki/Grammy_Hall_of_Fame "Grammy Hall of Fame").[25]

## In popular culture

[Janice](/wiki/Janice_\(muppet\) "Janice \(muppet\)") sang this song as an
opening number to an episode of _[The Muppet Show](/wiki/The_Muppet_Show "The
Muppet Show")_ where other members of [Dr. Teeth and The Electric
Mayhem](/wiki/Dr._Teeth_and_The_Electric_Mayhem "Dr. Teeth and The Electric
Mayhem") were pretending to rescue her from a Hindu human sacrifice.

_[Sesame Street](/wiki/Sesame_Street "Sesame Street")_ spoofed this song as
"With a Little Yelp from My Friends", sung by a dog named Moe Cocker, who
spoofs Joe Cocker, and the arrangement is clearly based on Cocker's
version.[26]

The [Animaniacs](/wiki/Animaniacs "Animaniacs") sketch [Woodstock
Slappy](/wiki/Slappy_Squirrel "Slappy Squirrel") features Joe Cocker singing
the song.

The song was featured in the _[EastEnders](/wiki/EastEnders "EastEnders")_
[2007 Children in Need sketch](/wiki/Children_in_Need_2007 "Children in Need
2007") where the cast sang to famous Beatles songs, the song was the last to
be sung by the cast with the characters of [Ronnie
Mitchell](/wiki/Ronnie_Mitchell "Ronnie Mitchell"), [Roxy
Mitchell](/wiki/Roxy_Mitchell "Roxy Mitchell"), [Chelsea
Fox](/wiki/Chelsea_Fox "Chelsea Fox"), [Carly Wicks](/wiki/Carly_Wicks "Carly
Wicks"), [Jane Beale](/wiki/Jane_Beale "Jane Beale"), [Lucy
Beale](/wiki/Lucy_Beale "Lucy Beale"), [Peter Beale](/wiki/Peter_Beale "Peter
Beale"), [Ben Mitchell](/wiki/Ben_Mitchell_\(EastEnders\) "Ben Mitchell
\(EastEnders\)"), [Zainab Masood](/wiki/Zainab_Masood "Zainab Masood"),
[Masood Ahmed](/wiki/Masood_Ahmed "Masood Ahmed"), [Honey
Mitchell](/wiki/Honey_Mitchell "Honey Mitchell"), [Dawn
Swann](/wiki/Dawn_Swann "Dawn Swann") and [Mickey Miller](/wiki/Mickey_Miller
"Mickey Miller") singing the majority of the song.

The Joe Cocker version was used as the title music for the 1988–1993
television series _[The Wonder Years](/wiki/The_Wonder_Years "The Wonder
Years")_.

The Cocker version appears in a [2017](/wiki/2017_in_television "2017 in
television") [TV commercial](/wiki/TV_commercial "TV commercial") for
[Volkswagen](/wiki/Volkswagen "Volkswagen").

"Lend me your ears" is a [Shakespearean](/wiki/Shakespearean "Shakespearean")
reference, taken from the "[Friends, Romans,
countrymen](/wiki/Friends,_Romans,_countrymen "Friends, Romans, countrymen")"
speech in _[Julius Caesar](/wiki/Julius_Caesar_\(play\) "Julius Caesar
\(play\)")_ and used at the time as a popular way of asking people to listen.

"With a Little Help from My Friends" was played as wake-up music on [Space
Shuttle](/wiki/Space_Shuttle "Space Shuttle") Mission [STS-61](/wiki/STS-61
"STS-61").[27]

On _[Saturday Night Live](/wiki/Saturday_Night_Live "Saturday Night Live")_ ,
Season-1 Ep.3: [John Belushi](/wiki/John_Belushi "John Belushi") performed a
full-length impression of Cocker singing this song.[28]

The cult [PBS](/wiki/PBS "PBS") film _[The Lathe of
Heaven](/wiki/The_Lathe_of_Heaven_\(film\) "The Lathe of Heaven \(film\)")_
(from 1980) uses the original recording of the song. The main character
(George Orr), who can manipulate reality with his dreams, comes upon a 45 of
the song at a novelty shop run by an alien. The alien hands George the 45
saying "Help is available." The song plays in the soundtrack and morphs into a
synthesizer version. The film was out of circulation for over 20 years. When
it was finally re-aired on PBS and released on DVD in 2001, many fans were
upset that the original Beatles recording was replaced by a singer with an
acoustic guitar. This was due to changes in publishing rights that have
occurred since 1980 involving the dissolution of The Beatles' original
Northern Songs and the acquisition by Sony/ATV (partly owned by the Jackson
family).[_[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed
"Wikipedia:Citation needed")_]
